body:
That wasn't my change. Oracle is used when it's provided, open-jdk is
selected otherwise. In cases where there was no jdk without a side effect,
I continued that pattern.

On Tue, Feb 23, 2016 at 7:38 AM, nickwallen notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Why install OpenJDK as part of deployment/roles/yaf/tasks/main.yml?
> Previously the scripts were standardized on Oracle Java 8, which I believe
> is preferred for HDP, no?
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-metron/pull/28#issuecomment-187682551
> .
Also, seeing that promisc enablement was turned off as part of this change in `deployment/vagrant/multinode-vagrant/Vagrantfile`.  This needs to be on to sniff network traffic.
I don't see that change- which line?

```
# enable the hostmanager plugin
    config.hostmanager.enabled = true
 @@ -44,11 +44,6 @@ Vagrant.configure(2) do |config|
        node.vm.provider "virtualbox" do |vb|
          vb.memory = host[:memory]
          vb.cpus = host[:cpus]
 -
 -        # enable promisc mode on the network interface
 -        if host.has_key?(:promisc)
 -          vb.customize ["modifyvm", :id, "--nicpromisc#{host[:promisc]}", "allow-all"]
 -        end
        end
```
Got it, thanks- I'll get that back in, move the variables and re-test.
Testing passed with latest commit. Thanks for looking it over!
+1 Change looks good.  Thanks for the fix.
Looks good.  +1

Much of the topology stuff was an attempt to "feed the machine" in order to get the deployment to function. Happy to get some feedback as to how to correctly wire the topology together.

Thanks!

I feel like this commit may be close- please let me know what you think.

2) Standalone - Pass
3) Full Deploy - Pass
4) Topology Deployment - Working
5) Kafka Topic retention and partitions are now configurable

That is already a problem with 'master' currently, which is addressed in METRON-57.  If you can merge that one, it will address the problem.
Would like to see +1's from the experts, both @cestella and @dlyle65535, before this gets merged.

Out of control.  Need to create a separate PR.  Daft!
Ok +1

Yes, I think it would make sense to tie the key to the environment.  I can add that change.
The key pair now uses the key name.  Ready for merge.
I'm +1. Looks great. Ran a full cluster install with it.
+1, looks good
Merged with master
@dlyle65535 - Please take a gander

Overall looks good. I'll run it up. Originally, I only intended this to run once at first provisioning. You may want to consider enforcing that. I wouldn't move a partition end on a system after initial buildout.
@merrimanr - Take a quick look at the changes made to the pcap service.  Hopefully minimal impact to what you are working on.
This looks good to me, but I'm going to defer to @merrimanr to give it a second glance since he's in that code right now.
+1 from me.  Only change I had to make was the -port option and it looks like you found it as well.

Yes, this is a gap, but one that did already exist.  At the very least this change is not making things worse.

Personally I would not be too concerned about this. if conditions ever exist for the 'expand-volume' logic to fire when it shouldn't then there are likely larger problems in the environment.  The kind of 'larger' problems that might cause someone to just shoot the node in the head and start over anyways.  I could be wrong though.

I think the gap was that since we still have some work to do on idempoentence in the scripts, I mistakenly believed that no one would run these twice and expect to be happy with the result. It that holds (and potentially is documented somewhere) I'm good.
Are you saying that we should not merge this PR until everything is completely idempotent?  Totally open to a -1 if you think there is a better way that we should do this.

No, not at all. Just don't want to introduce more places where it breaks.

Er..intentionally. :)
+1 as is. Thanks!
+1 this looks good, merging now.  Also necessary for the apache release.

@cestella Can we use this mechanism to load the threat intel or other forms of data that are currently being loaded elsewhere?  

This mechanism will really help in creating complementary test data sets. For example where the same IPs need to be used in pcap, threat intel, asset enrichment, etc data sets to enable correlation within Metron.

@dlyle65535 @cestella @merrimanr I'd love to see this go in.  It is a great way to extract test setup from the cluster deployment process.  I'd like to use this mechanism to setup some additional tests when I return.  Please review and let me know.
Thanks for the contribution.  Will verify shortly

Good catch! Thanks for the PR. 

Lately, I'm a little reluctant to add ignore_errors without a fail block immediately following. In this case, you could add a register: result to the Upload grok patterns task followed by a fail task that fails if "File exists" isn't in stdout. That would make sure it didn't ignore different types of errors.

Since we're interacting with hdfs immediately prior to the file copy, I think ignore_errors would be okay here, but if you had the time to add the fail block, it would be preferred. It demonstrates the preferred pattern and gives others a better example to follow.

What do you think?

Sounds like a plan @dlyle65535! So, based on what you were saying about the register and the fail block, I found this guy...

http://docs.ansible.com/ansible/playbooks_error_handling.html#controlling-what-defines-failure

Looks like the "ignore_errors + register + the separate fail block w/ the explicit message" pattern can be collapsed into a "register + failed_when" pattern, so something like this maybe...

``` yaml
register: put_result
failed_when: "put_result | failed and 'File exists' not in put_result.stderr"
```

And then in a completely different direction, looks like the "[copyFromLocal](https://hadoop.apache.org/docs/r2.7.2/hadoop-project-dist/hadoop-common/FileSystemShell.html#copyFromLocal)" (instead of the put) command supports the force (-f) flag... which would just overwrite the destination without throwing an error.

So thoughts on which you'd prefer...
1. Separate Fail Block w/ Messaging.
2. Failed_when that will do a normal fail if it's not a fail exists issue
3. Use a copyFromLocal w/ the override flag (instead of the put)

From my perspective, # 3 would be a good approach. If you have a different opinion, I'm happy to support it.

Thanks for digging into it!

In some of my own branches I had been using `hdfs dfs -put -f ...` successfully.  I'd recommend that.  I don't really understand the difference between that and `copyFromLocal`, but either should probably work.

https://github.com/nickwallen/incubator-metron/blob/METRON-80/deployment/roles/metron_streaming/tasks/grok_upload.yml
No, please go ahead with your fix.  Thanks for all the research.

+1 Thank you for your contribution!

I've opened METRON-89: Rerunning playbook halts due to hdfs.

Just commented on the METRON-89 ticket, but the additional flag (-f) was added to the PR/commit a few days ago -- so not sure if I need to do anything else here?
+1 from me.

Casey and David, just pushed a commit to address your comments (integration tests ran).  

Bryan, thanks for commenting, that's a great point.  It's a realtime streaming application so handling a high volume of writes and seeing updates in near real time are important.  What strategy would you suggest?

@merrimanr I think using the auto commits would be the way to go and gives you the flexibility to tune the values to your needs. You could still leave the optional commit in the writer in case it is needed for testing or anything else. 

In terms of the appropriate commit intervals, a lot of it is trial and error depending on how much latency the application can tolerate to see updates, vs. speed & amount of incoming data. Soft commits are lightweight operations (some overhead) that will make updates visible, but the updates aren't flushed to disk until a hard commit. 

This post has a good description of the tread-offs:
https://lucidworks.com/blog/2013/08/23/understanding-transaction-logs-softcommit-and-commit-in-sorlcloud/

Metron might be the "Index-Heavy, Query-light" scenario? but not sure.
Thanks for you input @bbende.  I've committed the change.
+1 for sure.
+1.  Eventually we want to move this setting to zookeeper.
Looks good.  Mind squashing your commits?

```
Unapproved licenses:

  metron-streaming/Metron-Common/src/test/java/org/apache/metron/bolt/ConfiguredBoltTest.java

  metron-streaming/Metron-Common/src/test/java/org/apache/metron/utils/ConfigurationsUtilsTest.java
```

So, since this touches the ansible stuff, could we please get someone else to verify that singlenode vagrant isn't broken in a too-subtle-for-me-to-detect way.  If that's ok and there's a followup PR with the testing utility, then I'm +1.

+1 perfecto
Sorry to be a pain, but the rest of the file is nicely formatted.  The additional line seems to be indented a bit too much.  Could we run a quick re-format on that?
Last time I checked, there was a pretty large bit of work to get EC2 working with Centos7 as well. Has that changed or is the plan to defer packet-capture until we have Centos7 deployment working?

I think that's a bridge to cross later once we refine specific deployment topologies.  The packet capture process differs from the rest of the sensors that we have to date and requires a bit of special treatment.
- This packet capture process is overkill and too cumbersome in demo/test environments.  It is really only useful for high-throughput production environments.
- Using kernel bypass technology like this means that the packet capture process does not share well with others.  No other sensors leveraging libpcap drivers can share the same network interface.
- Packet capture would most always run on a node isolated from the rest of your cluster.  The cluster could be running CentOS 6 while this runs on CentOS 7.  
- This process has to be run close to your data.  I don't foresee this running "in the cloud." It could potentially be used in a hybrid cloud deployment sending data from a secured network to the cloud.
+1 from me

@cestella I was able to use this tool to build valid libpcap-compliant files from packet data in Kafka.  This was successful when using either the 'new pycapa' (`metron-sensors/pycapa`) or the 'fast packet capture'  (`metron-sensors/packet-capture`) code as the source of packet data.  This kind of test has not been automated, but at least now I have the means to automate it.

Also, this should help show exactly what kind of headers we need added by your 'pcap extraction topology' effort.

I don't think the license for argparse is kosher. Please investigate and
remove if inappropriate or adjust the license file if that's required.
